También significa que la altura del cuerpo de una ventana nunca puede exceder su altura total devuelta por window-total-height .

trans-unit.source: If pos-or-prop is a marker or number, this function returns a non-nil value if the text at that position is currently invisible.
trans-unit.target: Si pos-or-prop es un marcador o un número, esta función devuelve un valor no nil si el texto en esa posición es actualmente invisible.

trans-unit.source: If pos-or-prop is any other kind of Lisp object, that is taken to mean a possible value of the invisible text or overlay property. In that case, this function returns a non-nil value if that value would cause text to become invisible, based on the current value of buffer-invisibility-spec.
trans-unit.target: Si pos-or-prop es cualquier otro tipo de objeto Lisp, se considera que significa un valor posible del texto invisible o propiedad de superposición. En ese caso, esta función devuelve un valor no nil si ese valor haría que el texto se volviera invisible, según el valor actual de buffer-invisibility-spec .

trans-unit.source: If pos is at the beginning of its field, and escape-from-edge is non-nil, then the return value is always the beginning of the preceding field that ends at pos, regardless of the stickiness of the field properties around pos.
trans-unit.target: Si pos está al principio de su campo, y escape-from-edge no es nil , entonces el valor de retorno es siempre el comienzo del campo anterior que termina en pos , independientemente de la rigidez de las propiedades del field alrededor de pos .

trans-unit.source: If pos is at the end of its field, and escape-from-edge is non-nil, then the return value is always the end of the following field that begins at pos, regardless of the stickiness of the field properties around pos.
trans-unit.target: Si pos está al final de su campo y escape-from-edge no es nil , entonces el valor de retorno es siempre el final del siguiente campo que comienza en pos , independientemente de la rigidez de las propiedades del field alrededor de pos .

trans-unit.source: If position is nil or a marker that points nowhere, then marker is set to point nowhere.
trans-unit.target: Si la position es nil o un marcador que no apunta a ninguna parte, entonces el marker se establece para que no apunte a ninguna parte.

trans-unit.source: If position is t, it means to use the current mouse position (or the top-left corner of the frame if the mouse is not available on a text terminal). If position is nil, it means to precompute the key binding equivalents for the keymaps specified in menu, without actually displaying or popping up the menu.
trans-unit.target: Si la position es t , significa usar la posición actual del mouse (o la esquina superior izquierda del marco si el mouse no está disponible en una terminal de texto). Si la position es nil , significa precalcular los equivalentes de vinculación de teclas para los mapas de teclas especificados en el menu , sin mostrar o hacer aparecer el menú.

trans-unit.source: If position is at the end of object, both the CAR and the CDR of the value are nil.
trans-unit.target: Si la position está al final del object , tanto el CAR como el CDR del valor son nil .

trans-unit.source: If position is visible, pos-visible-in-window-p returns t if partially is nil; if partially is non-nil, and the character following position is fully visible, it returns a list of the form (x y), where x and y are the pixel coordinates relative to the top left corner of the window; otherwise it returns an extended list of the form (x y rtop rbot rowh vpos), where rtop and rbot specify the number of off-window pixels at the top and bottom of the row at position, rowh specifies the visible height of that row, and vpos specifies the vertical position (zero-based row number) of that row.
trans-unit.target: Si la position es visible, pos-visible-in-window-p devuelve t si partially es nil ; si partially es no nil , y el carácter siguiente position es totalmente visible, devuelve una lista de la forma (x y) , donde x e y son las coordenadas de píxeles relativas a la esquina superior izquierda de la ventana; de lo contrario, devuelve una lista extendida de la forma (x y rtop rbot rowh vpos) , donde rtop y rbot especifica el número de píxeles fuera de la ventana en la parte superior e inferior de la fila en la position , rowh especifica la altura visible de esa fila y vpos especifica la posición vertical (número de fila basado en cero) de esa fila.

trans-unit.source: If predicate is non-nil and if collection contains several strings that are equal to each other, as determined by compare-strings according to completion-ignore-case, then predicate should accept either all or none of them. Otherwise, the return value of test-completion is essentially unpredictable.
trans-unit.target: Si el predicate no es nil y si la collection contiene varias cadenas que son iguales entre sí, según lo determinado por compare-strings acuerdo con la completion-ignore-case , entonces el predicate debe aceptar todas o ninguna. De lo contrario, el valor de retorno de test-completion de la prueba es esencialmente impredecible.

trans-unit.source: If predicate is non-nil, it specifies a function of one argument that decides which file names are acceptable completion alternatives. A file name is an acceptable value if predicate returns non-nil for it.
trans-unit.target: Si el predicate no es nil , especifica una función de un argumento que decide qué nombres de archivo son alternativas de finalización aceptables. Un nombre de archivo es un valor aceptable si el predicate devuelve un valor distinto de nil .

trans-unit.source: If prefix is given, it should be a prefix key sequence; then accessible-keymaps includes only the submaps whose prefixes start with prefix. These elements look just as they do in the value of (accessible-keymaps); the only difference is that some elements are omitted.
trans-unit.target: Si prefix se da, debe ser una secuencia de teclas de prefijo; luego accessible-keymaps incluyen solo los submapas cuyos prefijos comienzan con prefix . Estos elementos tienen el mismo aspecto que en el valor de (accessible-keymaps) ; la única diferencia es que se omiten algunos elementos.

trans-unit.source: If prefix is non-nil, it should be a prefix key; then the listing includes only keys that start with prefix.
trans-unit.target: Si el prefix no es nil , debería ser una clave de prefijo; entonces la lista incluye solo claves que comienzan con prefix .

trans-unit.source: If preserve is nil, this means to stop preserving the height/width of window, lifting any respective restraint induced by a previous call of this function for window. Calling enlarge-window, shrink-window or fit-window-to-buffer with window as argument may also remove the respective restraint.
trans-unit.target: Si preserve es nil , esto significa dejar de conservar la altura / ancho de la window , levantando cualquier restricción respectiva inducida por una llamada previa de esta función para window . Llamar a enlarge-window , shrink-window o fit-window-to-buffer con window como argumento también puede eliminar la restricción respectiva.

trans-unit.source: If pretend is non-nil, then Emacs displays height lines of output in frame, but does not change its value for the actual height of the frame. This is only useful on text terminals. Using a smaller height than the terminal actually implements may be useful to reproduce behavior observed on a smaller screen, or if the terminal malfunctions when using its whole screen. Setting the frame height directly does not always work, because knowing the correct actual size may be necessary for correct cursor positioning on text terminals.
trans-unit.target: Si pretend es no- nil , entonces Emacs muestra las líneas de height de salida en el frame , pero no cambia su valor para la altura real del marco. Esto solo es útil en terminales de texto. Usar una altura menor que la que realmente implementa el terminal puede ser útil para reproducir el comportamiento observado en una pantalla más pequeña, o si el terminal no funciona correctamente al usar toda su pantalla. Establecer la altura del marco directamente no siempre funciona, porque conocer el tamaño real correcto puede ser necesario para colocar correctamente el cursor en los terminales de texto.

trans-unit.source: If process does not have a buffer, process-mark returns a marker that points nowhere.
trans-unit.target: Si el process no tiene un búfer, process-mark devuelve un marcador que no apunta a ninguna parte.

trans-unit.source: If <var>process</var> is a datagram connection or server, this function returns its remote peer address.
trans-unit.target: Si el <var>process</var> es una conexión de datagrama o un servidor, esta función devuelve su dirección de par remoto.

trans-unit.source: If <var>process</var> is a datagram connection or server, this function sets its remote peer address to <var>address</var>.
trans-unit.target: Si el <var>process</var> es una conexión de datagrama o un servidor, esta función establece la dirección del par remoto en <var>address</var> .

trans-unit.source: If process is a non-blocking network stream that hasn’t been fully set up yet, then this function will block until that has happened. If given the optional no-block parameter, this function will return nil instead of blocking.
trans-unit.target: Si el process es un flujo de red sin bloqueo que aún no se ha configurado por completo, esta función se bloqueará hasta que eso suceda. Si se le da el parámetro opcional no-block , esta función devolverá nil en lugar de bloquear.

trans-unit.source: If process is a process, and the argument just-this-one is non-nil, only output from that process is handled, suspending output from other processes until some output has been received from that process or the timeout expires. If just-this-one is an integer, also inhibit running timers. This feature is generally not recommended, but may be necessary for specific applications, such as speech synthesis.
trans-unit.target: Si el process es un proceso, y el argumento just-this-one no es nil , solo se maneja la salida de ese proceso, suspendiendo la salida de otros procesos hasta que se haya recibido alguna salida de ese proceso o expire el tiempo de espera. Si just-this-one es un número entero, inhiba también los temporizadores en ejecución. Esta función generalmente no se recomienda, pero puede ser necesaria para aplicaciones específicas, como la síntesis de voz.

trans-unit.source: If <var>program</var> exits with a non-zero exit status, this function signals an error.
trans-unit.target: Si el <var>program</var> a sale con un estado de salida distinto de cero, esta función indica un error.

trans-unit.source: If program is nil, Emacs opens a new pseudoterminal (pty) and associates its input and output with buffer-or-name, without creating a subprocess. In that case, the remaining arguments args are ignored.
trans-unit.target: Si el program a es nil , Emacs abre un nuevo pseudoterminal (pty) y asocia su entrada y salida con buffer-or-name , sin crear un subproceso. En ese caso, el resto de argumentos args son ignorados.

trans-unit.source: If prompt is non-nil, that becomes the overall prompt string for the keymap. The prompt string should be given for menu keymaps (see Defining Menus).
trans-unit.target: Si la prompt no es nil , se convierte en la cadena de solicitud general para el mapa de teclas. La cadena de solicitud debe proporcionarse para los mapas de teclas del menú (consulte Definición de menús ).

trans-unit.source: If <var>prompt</var> is supplied, it specifies a string for prompting the user. The prompt string is always displayed in the echo area, followed by a single ‘
trans-unit.target: Si se proporciona un <var>prompt</var> , especifica una cadena para preguntar al usuario. La cadena de solicitud siempre se muestra en el área de eco, seguida de un solo '

trans-unit.source: If props is nil, the effect is to get rid of all properties from the specified range of text. Here’s an example:
trans-unit.target: Si props es nil , el efecto es deshacerse de todas las propiedades del rango de texto especificado. He aquí un ejemplo:

trans-unit.source: If query-flag is nil, it replaces all occurrences; otherwise, it asks the user what to do about each one.
trans-unit.target: Si query-flag es nil , reemplaza todas las apariciones; de lo contrario, le pregunta al usuario qué hacer con cada uno.

trans-unit.source: If query-only is non-nil, it only lists processes whose query flag is non-nil. See Query Before Exit.
trans-unit.target: Si query-only no es nil , solo enumera los procesos cuyo indicador de consulta no es nil . Consulte Consulta antes de salir .

trans-unit.source: If quit-char is non-nil, it specifies the character to use for quitting. Normally this character is
trans-unit.target: If quit-char is non- nil , it specifies the character to use for quitting. Normally this character is

trans-unit.source: If read-function is non-nil, it should be a function, which is used instead of read to read expressions one by one. This function is called with one argument, the stream for reading input. You can also use the variable load-read-function (see How Programs Do Loading) to specify this function, but it is more robust to use the read-function argument.
trans-unit.target: If read-function is non- nil , it should be a function, which is used instead of read to read expressions one by one. This function is called with one argument, the stream for reading input. You can also use the variable load-read-function (see How Programs Do Loading) to specify this function, but it is more robust to use the read-function argument.

trans-unit.source: If read is non-nil, then default is also used as the input to read, if the user enters empty input. If default is a list of strings, the first string is used as the input. If default is nil, empty input results in an end-of-file error. However, in the usual case (where read is nil), read-from-minibuffer ignores default when the user enters empty input and returns an empty string, "". In this respect, it differs from all the other minibuffer input functions in this chapter.
trans-unit.target: If read is non- nil , then default is also used as the input to read , if the user enters empty input. If default is a list of strings, the first string is used as the input. If default is nil , empty input results in an end-of-file error. However, in the usual case (where read is nil ), read-from-minibuffer ignores default when the user enters empty input and returns an empty string, "" . In this respect, it differs from all the other minibuffer input functions in this chapter.

trans-unit.source: If real-binding is nil, then item-string appears in the menu but cannot be selected.
trans-unit.target: If real-binding is nil , then item-string appears in the menu but cannot be selected.

trans-unit.source: If real-binding is a symbol and has a non-nilmenu-enable property, that property is an expression that controls whether the menu item is enabled. Every time the keymap is used to display a menu, Emacs evaluates the expression, and it enables the menu item only if the expression’s value is non-nil. When a menu item is disabled, it is displayed in a fuzzy fashion, and cannot be selected.
trans-unit.target: If real-binding is a symbol and has a non- nil menu-enable property, that property is an expression that controls whether the menu item is enabled. Every time the keymap is used to display a menu, Emacs evaluates the expression, and it enables the menu item only if the expression’s value is non- nil . When a menu item is disabled, it is displayed in a fuzzy fashion, and cannot be selected.

trans-unit.source: If record-flag is non-nil, then this command and its arguments are unconditionally added to the list command-history. Otherwise, the command is added only if it uses the minibuffer to read an argument. See Command History.
trans-unit.target: If record-flag is non- nil , then this command and its arguments are unconditionally added to the list command-history . Otherwise, the command is added only if it uses the minibuffer to read an argument. See Command History.

trans-unit.source: If regexp-flag is non-nil, then from-string is considered a regular expression; otherwise, it must match literally. If delimited-flag is non-nil, then only replacements surrounded by word boundaries are considered.
trans-unit.target: If regexp-flag is non- nil , then from-string is considered a regular expression; otherwise, it must match literally. If delimited-flag is non- nil , then only replacements surrounded by word boundaries are considered.

trans-unit.source: If <var>registry</var> is specified but not available, Emacs will try the other registries given in <var>alternate-registries</var>, one by one, until it finds a registry that does exist.
trans-unit.target: If <var>registry</var> is specified but not available, Emacs will try the other registries given in <var>alternate-registries</var> , one by one, until it finds a registry that does exist.

trans-unit.source: If <var>rehash-size</var> is an integer, it should be positive, and the hash table grows by adding approximately that much to the nominal size. If <var>rehash-size</var> is floating point, it had better be greater than 1, and the hash table grows by multiplying the old size by approximately that number.
trans-unit.target: If <var>rehash-size</var> is an integer, it should be positive, and the hash table grows by adding approximately that much to the nominal size. If <var>rehash-size</var> is floating point, it had better be greater than 1, and the hash table grows by multiplying the old size by approximately that number.

trans-unit.source: If remote is non-nil, and default-directory is a remote directory, program is searched on the respective remote host.
trans-unit.target: If remote is non- nil , and default-directory is a remote directory, program is searched on the respective remote host.

trans-unit.source: If repeat-count is non-nil, it should be an integer. Then it specifies how many times to use each of the strings in the replacements list before advancing cyclically to the next one.
trans-unit.target: If repeat-count is non- nil , it should be an integer. Then it specifies how many times to use each of the strings in the replacements list before advancing cyclically to the next one.

trans-unit.source: If repeat is nil, the timer runs just once, the first time Emacs remains idle for a long enough time. More often repeat is non-nil, which means to run the timer each time Emacs remains idle for secs seconds.
trans-unit.target: If repeat is nil , the timer runs just once, the first time Emacs remains idle for a long enough time. More often repeat is non- nil , which means to run the timer each time Emacs remains idle for secs seconds.

trans-unit.source: If replace is non-nil, then kill-new replaces the first element of the kill ring with string, rather than pushing string onto the kill ring.
trans-unit.target: If replace is non- nil , then kill-new replaces the first element of the kill ring with string , rather than pushing string onto the kill ring.

trans-unit.source: If replacements is a cons cell, (function . data), this means to call function after each match to get the replacement text. This function is called with two arguments: data, and the number of replacements already made.
trans-unit.target: If replacements is a cons cell, (function . data) , this means to call function after each match to get the replacement text. This function is called with two arguments: data , and the number of replacements already made.

trans-unit.source: If reseat is non-nil, all markers on the match-list list are reseated to point to nowhere.
trans-unit.target: If reseat is non- nil , all markers on the match-list list are reseated to point to nowhere.

trans-unit.source: If reseat is non-nil, all markers on the reuse list are reseated to point to nowhere.
trans-unit.target: If reseat is non- nil , all markers on the reuse list are reseated to point to nowhere.

trans-unit.source: If restriction is non-nil, it should be a list of charsets to search. Alternatively, it can be a coding system, in which case the returned charset must be supported by that coding system (see Coding Systems).
trans-unit.target: If restriction is non- nil , it should be a list of charsets to search. Alternatively, it can be a coding system, in which case the returned charset must be supported by that coding system (see Coding Systems).

trans-unit.source: If reuse is non-nil, it should be a list. In that case, match-data stores the match data in reuse. That is, reuse is destructively modified. reuse does not need to have the right length. If it is not long enough to contain the match data, it is extended. If it is too long, the length of reuse stays the same, but the elements that were not used are set to nil. The purpose of this feature is to reduce the need for garbage collection.
trans-unit.target: If reuse is non- nil , it should be a list. In that case, match-data stores the match data in reuse . That is, reuse is destructively modified. reuse does not need to have the right length. If it is not long enough to contain the match data, it is extended. If it is too long, the length of reuse stays the same, but the elements that were not used are set to nil . The purpose of this feature is to reduce the need for garbage collection.

trans-unit.source: If reuseaddr-flag is non-nil (the default) for a stream server process, allow this server to reuse a specific port number (see :service), unless another process on this host is already listening on that port. If reuseaddr-flag is nil, there may be a period of time after the last use of that port (by any process on the host) where it is not possible to make a new server on that port.
trans-unit.target: If reuseaddr-flag is non- nil (the default) for a stream server process, allow this server to reuse a specific port number (see :service ), unless another process on this host is already listening on that port. If reuseaddr-flag is nil , there may be a period of time after the last use of that port (by any process on the host) where it is not possible to make a new server on that port.

trans-unit.source: If reverse is non-nil, the sort is in reverse order.
trans-unit.target: If reverse is non- nil , the sort is in reverse order.

trans-unit.source: If rigid is non-nil (interactively, with a prefix argument), then after this command indents a line or inserts a tab, it also rigidly indents the entire balanced expression which starts at the beginning of the current line, in order to reflect the new indentation. This argument is ignored if the command indents the region.
trans-unit.target: If rigid is non- nil (interactively, with a prefix argument), then after this command indents a line or inserts a tab, it also rigidly indents the entire balanced expression which starts at the beginning of the current line, in order to reflect the new indentation. This argument is ignored if the command indents the region.

trans-unit.source: If seconds is nil, Emacs is considered idle while waiting for user input to arrive. Idle timers—those created with run-with-idle-timer (see Idle Timers)—can run during this period. However, if seconds is non-nil, the state of idleness remains unchanged. If Emacs is non-idle when read-event is called, it remains non-idle throughout the operation of read-event; if Emacs is idle (which can happen if the call happens inside an idle timer), it remains idle.
trans-unit.target: If seconds is nil , Emacs is considered idle while waiting for user input to arrive. Idle timers—those created with run-with-idle-timer (see Idle Timers)—can run during this period. However, if seconds is non- nil , the state of idleness remains unchanged. If Emacs is non-idle when read-event is called, it remains non-idle throughout the operation of read-event ; if Emacs is idle (which can happen if the call happens inside an idle timer), it remains idle.

trans-unit.source: If seconds is non-nil, it should be a number specifying the maximum time to wait for input, in seconds. If no input arrives within that time, read-event stops waiting and returns nil. A floating point seconds means to wait for a fractional number of seconds. Some systems support only a whole number of seconds; on these systems, seconds is rounded down. If seconds is nil, read-event waits as long as necessary for input to arrive.
trans-unit.target: If seconds is non- nil , it should be a number specifying the maximum time to wait for input, in seconds. If no input arrives within that time, read-event stops waiting and returns nil . A floating point seconds means to wait for a fractional number of seconds. Some systems support only a whole number of seconds; on these systems, seconds is rounded down. If seconds is nil , read-event waits as long as necessary for input to arrive.

trans-unit.source: If separation is 0 and to is neither nil nor numerically equal to from, number-sequence signals an error, since those arguments specify an infinite sequence.
trans-unit.target: If separation is 0 and to is neither nil nor numerically equal to from , number-sequence signals an error, since those arguments specify an infinite sequence.

trans-unit.source: If separators is nil (or omitted), the default is the value of split-string-default-separators and the function behaves as if omit-nulls were t.
trans-unit.target: If separators is nil (or omitted), the default is the value of split-string-default-separators and the function behaves as if omit-nulls were t .

trans-unit.source: If separators is omitted or nil, it defaults to "\\s-+", which is a regular expression that matches one or more characters with whitespace syntax (see Syntax Class Table).
trans-unit.target: If separators is omitted or nil , it defaults to "\\s-+" , which is a regular expression that matches one or more characters with whitespace syntax (see Syntax Class Table).

trans-unit.source: If sequence is a list, delete is to delq as member is to memq: it uses equal to compare elements with object, like member; when it finds an element that matches, it cuts the element out just as delq would. As with delq, you should typically use the return value by assigning it to the variable which held the original list.
trans-unit.target: If sequence is a list, delete is to delq as member is to memq : it uses equal to compare elements with object , like member ; when it finds an element that matches, it cuts the element out just as delq would. As with delq , you should typically use the return value by assigning it to the variable which held the original list.

trans-unit.source: If <var>sequence</var> is empty, this function signals an error.
trans-unit.target: If <var>sequence</var> is empty, this function signals an error.

trans-unit.source: If server-flag is non-nil, create a server. Otherwise, create a connection. For a stream type server, server-flag may be an integer, which then specifies the length of the queue of pending connections to the server. The default queue length is 5.
trans-unit.target: If server-flag is non- nil , create a server. Otherwise, create a connection. For a stream type server, server-flag may be an integer, which then specifies the length of the queue of pending connections to the server. The default queue length is 5.

trans-unit.source: If set-minimum is non-nil, the new scroll amount becomes the lower bound for automatic scrolling; that is, automatic scrolling will not scroll a window to a column less than the value returned by this function. Interactive calls pass non-nil for set-minimum.
trans-unit.target: If set-minimum is non- nil , the new scroll amount becomes the lower bound for automatic scrolling; that is, automatic scrolling will not scroll a window to a column less than the value returned by this function. Interactive calls pass non- nil for set-minimum .

trans-unit.source: If side is t or right, the new window is placed on the right of window. If side is left, the new window is placed on the left of window. In both these cases, size specifies a total window width, in columns.
trans-unit.target: If side is t or right , the new window is placed on the right of window . If side is left , the new window is placed on the left of window . In both these cases, size specifies a total window width, in columns.

trans-unit.source: If size is nil, this function obeys the variables window-min-height and window-min-width (see Window Sizes). Thus, it signals an error if splitting would result in making a window smaller than those variables specify. However, a non-nil value for size causes those variables to be ignored; in that case, the smallest allowable window is considered to be one that has space for a text area one line tall and/or two columns wide.
trans-unit.target: If size is nil , this function obeys the variables window-min-height and window-min-width (see Window Sizes). Thus, it signals an error if splitting would result in making a window smaller than those variables specify. However, a non- nil value for size causes those variables to be ignored; in that case, the smallest allowable window is considered to be one that has space for a text area one line tall and/or two columns wide.

trans-unit.source: If <var>spec-alist</var> contains more than one association with the same <var>letter</var>, the closest one to the start of the list is used.
trans-unit.target: If <var>spec-alist</var> contains more than one association with the same <var>letter</var> , the closest one to the start of the list is used.

trans-unit.source: If <var>spec-alist</var> contains more unique <var>letter</var> keys than there are unique specification characters in <var>template</var>, the unused keys are simply ignored.
trans-unit.target: If <var>spec-alist</var> contains more unique <var>letter</var> keys than there are unique specification characters in <var>template</var> , the unused keys are simply ignored.

trans-unit.source: If spec_version is nil, the server supports a specification prior to ‘
trans-unit.target: If spec_version is nil , the server supports a specification prior to ‘

trans-unit.source: If start is nil, then the command writes the entire buffer contents (not just the accessible portion) to the file and ignores end.
trans-unit.target: If start is nil , then the command writes the entire buffer contents (not just the accessible portion) to the file and ignores end .

trans-unit.source: If start is a string, then write-region writes or appends that string, rather than text from the buffer. end is ignored in this case.
trans-unit.target: If start is a string, then write-region writes or appends that string, rather than text from the buffer. end is ignored in this case.

trans-unit.source: If <var>start</var> is supplied, then reading begins at index <var>start</var> in the string (where the first character is at index 0). If you specify <var>end</var>, then reading is forced to stop just before that index, as if the rest of the string were not there.
trans-unit.target: If <var>start</var> is supplied, then reading begins at index <var>start</var> in the string (where the first character is at index 0). If you specify <var>end</var> , then reading is forced to stop just before that index, as if the rest of the string were not there.

trans-unit.source: If state is nil, start is assumed to be at the top level of parenthesis structure, such as the beginning of a function definition. Alternatively, you might wish to resume parsing in the middle of the structure. To do this, you must provide a state argument that describes the initial status of parsing. The value returned by a previous call to parse-partial-sexp will do nicely.
trans-unit.target: If state is nil , start is assumed to be at the top level of parenthesis structure, such as the beginning of a function definition. Alternatively, you might wish to resume parsing in the middle of the structure. To do this, you must provide a state argument that describes the initial status of parsing. The value returned by a previous call to parse-partial-sexp will do nicely.

trans-unit.source: If stderr is a buffer, Emacs will create a pipe process, the standard error process. This process will have the default filter (see Filter Functions), sentinel (see Sentinels), and coding systems (see Default Coding Systems). On the other hand, it will use query-flag as its query-on-exit flag (see Query Before Exit). It will be associated with the stderr buffer (see Process Buffers) and send its output (which is the standard error of the main process) there.
trans-unit.target: If stderr is a buffer, Emacs will create a pipe process, the standard error process. This process will have the default filter (see Filter Functions), sentinel (see Sentinels), and coding systems (see Default Coding Systems). On the other hand, it will use query-flag as its query-on-exit flag (see Query Before Exit). It will be associated with the stderr buffer (see Process Buffers) and send its output (which is the standard error of the main process) there.

trans-unit.source: If <var>stderr</var> is a pipe process, Emacs will use it as standard error process for the new process.
trans-unit.target: If <var>stderr</var> is a pipe process, Emacs will use it as standard error process for the new process.

trans-unit.source: If stopped is non-nil, start the network connection or server in the stopped state.
trans-unit.target: If stopped is non- nil , start the network connection or server in the stopped state.

trans-unit.source: If stopped is non-nil, start the process in the stopped state. In the stopped state, a pipe process does not accept incoming data, but you can send outgoing data. The stopped state is set by stop-process and cleared by continue-process (see Signals to Processes).
trans-unit.target: If stopped is non- nil , start the process in the stopped state. In the stopped state, a pipe process does not accept incoming data, but you can send outgoing data. The stopped state is set by stop-process and cleared by continue-process (see Signals to Processes).

trans-unit.source: If <var>string-or-char</var> is a string, this function capitalizes the initials of the words in <var>string-or-char</var>, without altering any letters other than the initials. It returns a new string whose contents are a copy of <var>string-or-char</var>, in which each word has had its initial letter converted to upper case.
trans-unit.target: If <var>string-or-char</var> is a string, this function capitalizes the initials of the words in <var>string-or-char</var> , without altering any letters other than the initials. It returns a new string whose contents are a copy of <var>string-or-char</var> , in which each word has had its initial letter converted to upper case.

trans-unit.source: If <var>string</var> does not reach <var>width</var>, then the result ends where <var>string</var> ends. If one multi-column character in <var>string</var> extends across the column <var>width</var>, that character is not included in the result. Thus, the result can fall short of <var>width</var> but cannot go beyond it.
trans-unit.target: If <var>string</var> does not reach <var>width</var> , then the result ends where <var>string</var> ends. If one multi-column character in <var>string</var> extends across the column <var>width</var> , that character is not included in the result. Thus, the result can fall short of <var>width</var> but cannot go beyond it.

trans-unit.source: If <var>string</var> is a multibyte string, this function returns <var>string</var> itself. Otherwise, it returns a new string with the same bytes as <var>string</var>, but treating each multibyte sequence as one character. This means that the value may have fewer characters than <var>string</var> has. If a byte sequence in <var>string</var> is invalid as a multibyte representation of a single character, each byte in the sequence is treated as a raw 8-bit byte. The newly-created string contains no text properties.
trans-unit.target: If <var>string</var> is a multibyte string, this function returns <var>string</var> itself. Otherwise, it returns a new string with the same bytes as <var>string</var> , but treating each multibyte sequence as one character. This means that the value may have fewer characters than <var>string</var> has. If a byte sequence in <var>string</var> is invalid as a multibyte representation of a single character, each byte in the sequence is treated as a raw 8-bit byte. The newly-created string contains no text properties.

trans-unit.source: If <var>string</var> is already a unibyte string, this function returns <var>string</var> itself. Otherwise, it returns a new string with the same bytes as <var>string</var>, but treating each byte as a separate character (so that the value may have more characters than <var>string</var>); as an exception, each eight-bit character representing a raw byte is converted into a single byte. The newly-created string contains no text properties.
trans-unit.target: If <var>string</var> is already a unibyte string, this function returns <var>string</var> itself. Otherwise, it returns a new string with the same bytes as <var>string</var> , but treating each byte as a separate character (so that the value may have more characters than <var>string</var> ); as an exception, each eight-bit character representing a raw byte is converted into a single byte. The newly-created string contains no text properties.

trans-unit.source: If string is non-nil, its characters are sent to Emacs’s superior shell, to be read as terminal input. The characters in string are not echoed by the superior shell; only the results appear.
trans-unit.target: If string is non- nil , its characters are sent to Emacs’s superior shell, to be read as terminal input. The characters in string are not echoed by the superior shell; only the results appear.

trans-unit.source: If <var>strings</var> is the empty list, the return value is a regexp that never matches anything.
trans-unit.target: If <var>strings</var> is the empty list, the return value is a regexp that never matches anything.

trans-unit.source: If subexp is non-nil, that says to replace just subexpression number subexp of the regexp that was matched, not the entire match. For example, after matching ‘
trans-unit.target: If subexp is non- nil , that says to replace just subexpression number subexp of the regexp that was matched, not the entire match. For example, after matching ‘

trans-unit.source: If subtype has the char-table-extra-slots symbol property, that specifies the number of extra slots in the char-table. This should be an integer between 0 and 10; otherwise, make-char-table raises an error. If subtype has no char-table-extra-slots symbol property (see Property Lists), the char-table has no extra slots.
trans-unit.target: If subtype has the char-table-extra-slots symbol property, that specifies the number of extra slots in the char-table. This should be an integer between 0 and 10; otherwise, make-char-table raises an error. If subtype has no char-table-extra-slots symbol property (see Property Lists), the char-table has no extra slots.

trans-unit.source: If suffix is non-nil, make-temp-file adds it at the end of the file name.
trans-unit.target: If suffix is non- nil , make-temp-file adds it at the end of the file name.

trans-unit.source: If symbol has a buffer-local binding in the current buffer, defvar acts on the default value, which is buffer-independent, rather than the buffer-local binding. It sets the default value if the default value is void. See Buffer-Local Variables.
trans-unit.target: If symbol has a buffer-local binding in the current buffer, defvar acts on the default value, which is buffer-independent, rather than the buffer-local binding. It sets the default value if the default value is void. See Buffer-Local Variables.

trans-unit.source: If symbol has a dynamic local binding, makunbound voids the current binding, and this voidness lasts only as long as the local binding is in effect. Afterwards, the previously shadowed local or global binding is reexposed; then the variable will no longer be void, unless the reexposed binding is void too.
trans-unit.target: If symbol has a dynamic local binding, makunbound voids the current binding, and this voidness lasts only as long as the local binding is in effect. Afterwards, the previously shadowed local or global binding is reexposed; then the variable will no longer be void, unless the reexposed binding is void too.

trans-unit.source: If symbol is already lexically bound (e.g., if the defvar form occurs in a let form with lexical binding enabled), then defvar sets the dynamic value. The lexical binding remains in effect until its binding construct exits. See Variable Scoping.
trans-unit.target: If symbol is already lexically bound (e.g., if the defvar form occurs in a let form with lexical binding enabled), then defvar sets the dynamic value. The lexical binding remains in effect until its binding construct exits. See Variable Scoping.

trans-unit.source: If symbol is non-nil, it should be a symbol; then this macro defines symbol as a function for popping up the menu (see Pop-Up Menus), with doc as its documentation string. symbol should not be quoted.
trans-unit.target: If symbol is non- nil , it should be a symbol; then this macro defines symbol as a function for popping up the menu (see Pop-Up Menus), with doc as its documentation string. symbol should not be quoted.

trans-unit.source: If symbol is not actually a symbol, a wrong-type-argument error is signaled.
trans-unit.target: If symbol is not actually a symbol, a wrong-type-argument error is signaled.

trans-unit.source: If symbol is part of a sequencing pattern seqpat (e.g., by using and, below), the binding is also available to the portion of seqpat following the appearance of symbol. This usage has some caveats, see caveats.
trans-unit.target: If symbol is part of a sequencing pattern seqpat (e.g., by using and , below), the binding is also available to the portion of seqpat following the appearance of symbol . This usage has some caveats, see caveats.

trans-unit.source: If symbol’s definition is a byte-code function object, byte-compile does nothing and returns nil. It does not compile the symbol’s definition again, since the original (non-compiled) code has already been replaced in the symbol’s function cell by the byte-compiled code.
trans-unit.target: If symbol ’s definition is a byte-code function object, byte-compile does nothing and returns nil . It does not compile the symbol’s definition again, since the original (non-compiled) code has already been replaced in the symbol’s function cell by the byte-compiled code.

trans-unit.source: If syntax is nil, the return value is nil. This is so that the expression
trans-unit.target: If syntax is nil , the return value is nil . This is so that the expression

trans-unit.source: If <var>syntaxes</var> starts with ‘
trans-unit.target: If <var>syntaxes</var> starts with ‘

trans-unit.source: If target is a relative file name, the resulting symbolic link is interpreted relative to the directory containing the symbolic link. See Relative File Names.
trans-unit.target: If target is a relative file name, the resulting symbolic link is interpreted relative to the directory containing the symbolic link. See Relative File Names.

trans-unit.source: If <var>template</var> contains the same specification character more than once, then the same <var>replacement</var> found in <var>spec-alist</var> is used as a basis for all of that character’s substitutions.
trans-unit.target: If <var>template</var> contains the same specification character more than once, then the same <var>replacement</var> found in <var>spec-alist</var> is used as a basis for all of that character’s substitutions.

trans-unit.source: If terminal is omitted or nil, it defaults to the selected frame’s terminal. terminal can also be a frame, meaning that frame’s terminal.
trans-unit.target: If terminal is omitted or nil , it defaults to the selected frame’s terminal. terminal can also be a frame, meaning that frame’s terminal.

trans-unit.source: If text is a string, make-temp-file inserts it in the file.
trans-unit.target: If text is a string, make-temp-file inserts it in the file.

trans-unit.source: If thread is blocked in condition-wait, this returns the condition variable.
trans-unit.target: If thread is blocked in condition-wait , this returns the condition variable.

trans-unit.source: If thread is blocked in mutex-lock, this returns the mutex.
trans-unit.target: If thread is blocked in mutex-lock , this returns the mutex.

trans-unit.source: If thread is blocked in thread-join, this returns the thread for which it is waiting.
trans-unit.target: If thread is blocked in thread-join , this returns the thread for which it is waiting.

trans-unit.source: If <var>thread</var> is the main thread, the signal is not propagated there. Instead, it is shown as message in the main thread.
trans-unit.target: If <var>thread</var> is the main thread, the signal is not propagated there. Instead, it is shown as message in the main thread.

trans-unit.source: If time has higher precision than nanoseconds, then this function truncates it to nanosecond precision towards negative infinity. This function signals an error if time (truncated to nanoseconds) cannot be represented by struct timespec. For example, if time_t is a 32-bit integer type, then a time value of ten billion seconds would signal an error, but a time value of 600 picoseconds would get truncated to zero.
trans-unit.target: If time has higher precision than nanoseconds, then this function truncates it to nanosecond precision towards negative infinity. This function signals an error if time (truncated to nanoseconds) cannot be represented by struct timespec . For example, if time_t is a 32-bit integer type, then a time value of ten billion seconds would signal an error, but a time value of 600 picoseconds would get truncated to zero.

trans-unit.source: If time is infinite or a NaN, this function signals an error. Otherwise, if time cannot be represented exactly, conversion truncates it toward minus infinity. When form is t, conversion is always exact so no truncation occurs, and the returned clock resolution is no less than that of time. By way of contrast, float-time can convert any Lisp time value without signaling an error, although the result might not be exact. See Time of Day.
trans-unit.target: If time is infinite or a NaN, this function signals an error. Otherwise, if time cannot be represented exactly, conversion truncates it toward minus infinity. When form is t , conversion is always exact so no truncation occurs, and the returned clock resolution is no less than that of time . By way of contrast, float-time can convert any Lisp time value without signaling an error, although the result might not be exact. See Time of Day.

trans-unit.source: If time is neither nil nor an integer flag returned by visited-file-modtime, it should be a Lisp time value (see Time of Day).
trans-unit.target: If time is neither nil nor an integer flag returned by visited-file-modtime , it should be a Lisp time value (see Time of Day).

trans-unit.source: If time is non-nil, then this function gives the new file the same last-modified time that the old one has. (This works on only some operating systems.) If setting the time gets an error, copy-file signals a file-date-error error. In an interactive call, a prefix argument specifies a non-nil value for time.
trans-unit.target: If time is non- nil , then this function gives the new file the same last-modified time that the old one has. (This works on only some operating systems.) If setting the time gets an error, copy-file signals a file-date-error error. In an interactive call, a prefix argument specifies a non- nil value for time .

trans-unit.source: If to-column is non-nil, it should be an integer specifying the number of columns of indentation; then this function gives each line exactly that much indentation, by either adding or deleting whitespace.
trans-unit.target: If to-column is non- nil , it should be an integer specifying the number of columns of indentation; then this function gives each line exactly that much indentation, by either adding or deleting whitespace.

trans-unit.source: If <var>to-fn</var> is a function, it is called with three arguments: <var>begin</var> and <var>end</var>, which specify the part of the buffer it should convert, and <var>buffer</var>, which specifies which buffer. There are two ways it can do the conversion:
trans-unit.target: If <var>to-fn</var> is a function, it is called with three arguments: <var>begin</var> and <var>end</var> , which specify the part of the buffer it should convert, and <var>buffer</var> , which specifies which buffer. There are two ways it can do the conversion:

trans-unit.source: If <var>to-fn</var> is a string, it is a shell command; Emacs runs the command as a filter to perform the conversion.
trans-unit.target: If <var>to-fn</var> is a string, it is a shell command; Emacs runs the command as a filter to perform the conversion.

trans-unit.source: If <var>tty</var> is already suspended, this function does nothing.
trans-unit.target: If <var>tty</var> is already suspended, this function does nothing.

trans-unit.source: If tty specifies a terminal device used by Emacs, this function relinquishes the device and restores it to its prior state. Frames that used the device continue to exist, but are not updated and Emacs doesn’t read input from them. tty can be a terminal object, a frame (meaning the terminal for that frame), or nil (meaning the terminal for the selected frame). See Multiple Terminals.
trans-unit.target: If tty specifies a terminal device used by Emacs, this function relinquishes the device and restores it to its prior state. Frames that used the device continue to exist, but are not updated and Emacs doesn’t read input from them. tty can be a terminal object, a frame (meaning the terminal for that frame), or nil (meaning the terminal for the selected frame). See Multiple Terminals.

trans-unit.source: If uid is non-nil, then it should be a number (a user-id) or a string (a login name). Then user-full-name returns the full name corresponding to that user-id or login name. If you specify a user-id or login name that isn’t defined, it returns nil.
trans-unit.target: If uid is non- nil , then it should be a number (a user-id) or a string (a login name). Then user-full-name returns the full name corresponding to that user-id or login name. If you specify a user-id or login name that isn’t defined, it returns nil .

trans-unit.source: If undo is present and non-nil, it is a function that will be called by yank-pop to undo the insertion of the current object. It is called with two arguments, the start and end of the current region. function can set yank-undo-function to override the undo value.
trans-unit.target: If undo is present and non- nil , it is a function that will be called by yank-pop to undo the insertion of the current object. It is called with two arguments, the start and end of the current region. function can set yank-undo-function to override the undo value.

trans-unit.source: If update is non-nil, window-end always returns an up-to-date value for where display ends, based on the current window-start value. If a previously saved value of that position is still valid, window-end returns that value; otherwise it computes the correct value by scanning the buffer text.
trans-unit.target: If update is non- nil , window-end always returns an up-to-date value for where display ends, based on the current window-start value. If a previously saved value of that position is still valid, window-end returns that value; otherwise it computes the correct value by scanning the buffer text.

trans-unit.source: If use-external-socket is non-nil use any sockets passed to Emacs on invocation instead of allocating one. This is used by the Emacs server code to allow on-demand socket activation. If Emacs wasn’t passed a socket, this option is silently ignored.
trans-unit.target: If use-external-socket is non- nil use any sockets passed to Emacs on invocation instead of allocating one. This is used by the Emacs server code to allow on-demand socket activation. If Emacs wasn’t passed a socket, this option is silently ignored.

trans-unit.source: If <var>value1</var> is a relative value for the face attribute <var>attribute</var>, returns it merged with the underlying value <var>value2</var>; otherwise, if <var>value1</var> is an absolute value for the face attribute <var>attribute</var>, returns <var>value1</var> unchanged.
trans-unit.target: If <var>value1</var> is a relative value for the face attribute <var>attribute</var> , returns it merged with the underlying value <var>value2</var> ; otherwise, if <var>value1</var> is an absolute value for the face attribute <var>attribute</var> , returns <var>value1</var> unchanged.

trans-unit.source: If value is specified, and symbol is void (i.e., it has no dynamically bound value; see Void Variables), then value is evaluated and symbol is set to the result. But if symbol is not void, value is not evaluated, and symbol’s value is left unchanged. If value is omitted, the value of symbol is not changed in any case.
trans-unit.target: If value is specified, and symbol is void (i.e., it has no dynamically bound value; see Void Variables), then value is evaluated and symbol is set to the result. But if symbol is not void, value is not evaluated, and symbol ’s value is left unchanged. If value is omitted, the value of symbol is not changed in any case.

trans-unit.source: If var is nil, that means no variable is bound. Then the error symbol and associated data are not available to the handler.
trans-unit.target: If var is nil , that means no variable is bound. Then the error symbol and associated data are not available to the handler.

trans-unit.source: If variable does not have a default value, then calling this command will give it a default value of nil. If variable already has a default value, that value remains unchanged. Subsequently calling makunbound on variable will result in a void buffer-local value and leave the default value unaffected.
trans-unit.target: If variable does not have a default value, then calling this command will give it a default value of nil . If variable already has a default value, that value remains unchanged. Subsequently calling makunbound on variable will result in a void buffer-local value and leave the default value unaffected.

trans-unit.source: If visible-ok is nil, other-buffer avoids returning a buffer visible in any window on any visible frame, except as a last resort. If visible-ok is non-nil, then it does not matter whether a buffer is displayed somewhere or not.
trans-unit.target: If visible-ok is nil , other-buffer avoids returning a buffer visible in any window on any visible frame, except as a last resort. If visible-ok is non- nil , then it does not matter whether a buffer is displayed somewhere or not.

trans-unit.source: If visit is t, then Emacs establishes an association between the buffer and the file: the buffer is then visiting that file. It also sets the last file modification time for the current buffer to filename’s modtime, and marks the buffer as not modified. This feature is used by save-buffer, but you probably should not use it yourself.
trans-unit.target: If visit is t , then Emacs establishes an association between the buffer and the file: the buffer is then visiting that file. It also sets the last file modification time for the current buffer to filename ’s modtime, and marks the buffer as not modified. This feature is used by save-buffer , but you probably should not use it yourself.

trans-unit.source: If visit is a string, it specifies the file name to visit. This way, you can write the data to one file (filename) while recording the buffer as visiting another file (visit). The argument visit is used in the echo area message and also for file locking; visit is stored in buffer-file-name. This feature is used to implement file-precious-flag; don’t use it yourself unless you really know what you’re doing.
trans-unit.target: If visit is a string, it specifies the file name to visit. This way, you can write the data to one file ( filename ) while recording the buffer as visiting another file ( visit ). The argument visit is used in the echo area message and also for file locking; visit is stored in buffer-file-name . This feature is used to implement file-precious-flag ; don’t use it yourself unless you really know what you’re doing.

trans-unit.source: If visit is non-nil, this function additionally marks the buffer as unmodified and sets up various fields in the buffer so that it is visiting the file filename: these include the buffer’s visited file name and its last save file modtime. This feature is used by find-file-noselect and you probably should not use it yourself.
trans-unit.target: If visit is non- nil , this function additionally marks the buffer as unmodified and sets up various fields in the buffer so that it is visiting the file filename : these include the buffer’s visited file name and its last save file modtime. This feature is used by find-file-noselect and you probably should not use it yourself.

trans-unit.source: If warn is non-nil, then this function issues a warning if an auto-save file exists and is more recent than the visited file.
trans-unit.target: If warn is non- nil , then this function issues a warning if an auto-save file exists and is more recent than the visited file.

trans-unit.source: If weak is key-and-value or t, both the key and the value must be live in order to preserve the association. Thus, the hash table does not protect either keys or values from garbage collection; if either one is collected as garbage, that removes the association.
trans-unit.target: If weak is key-and-value or t , both the key and the value must be live in order to preserve the association. Thus, the hash table does not protect either keys or values from garbage collection; if either one is collected as garbage, that removes the association.

trans-unit.source: If weak is key-or-value, either the key or the value can preserve the association. Thus, associations are removed from the hash table when both their key and value would be collected as garbage (if not for references from weak hash tables).
trans-unit.target: If weak is key-or-value , either the key or the value can preserve the association. Thus, associations are removed from the hash table when both their key and value would be collected as garbage (if not for references from weak hash tables).

trans-unit.source: If weak is value, then the hash table does not prevent values from being collected as garbage (if they are not referenced anywhere else); if a particular value does get collected, the corresponding association is removed from the hash table.
trans-unit.target: If weak is value , then the hash table does not prevent values from being collected as garbage (if they are not referenced anywhere else); if a particular value does get collected, the corresponding association is removed from the hash table.

trans-unit.source: If width is a number, it specifies that the space width should be width times the normal character width. width can also be a pixel width specification (see Pixel Specification).
trans-unit.target: If width is a number, it specifies that the space width should be width times the normal character width. width can also be a pixel width specification (see Pixel Specification).

trans-unit.source: If wildcards is non-nil, which is always true in an interactive call, then find-file expands wildcard characters in filename and visits all the matching files.
trans-unit.target: If wildcards is non- nil , which is always true in an interactive call, then find-file expands wildcard characters in filename and visits all the matching files.

trans-unit.source: If window is nil, it defaults to the selected window.
trans-unit.target: If window is nil , it defaults to the selected window.

trans-unit.source: If window is nil, it defaults to the selected window. If the window cannot be resized as demanded, an error is signaled.
trans-unit.target: If window is nil , it defaults to the selected window. If the window cannot be resized as demanded, an error is signaled.

trans-unit.source: If window is strongly dedicated to a buffer and buffer-or-name does not specify that buffer, this function signals an error. See Dedicated Windows.
trans-unit.target: If window is strongly dedicated to a buffer and buffer-or-name does not specify that buffer, this function signals an error. See Dedicated Windows.

trans-unit.source: If <var>window</var> is a live window, the new window inherits various properties from it, including margins and scroll bars. If <var>window</var> is an internal window, the new window inherits the properties of the window selected within <var>window</var>’s frame.
trans-unit.target: If <var>window</var> is a live window, the new window inherits various properties from it, including margins and scroll bars. If <var>window</var> is an internal window, the new window inherits the properties of the window selected within <var>window</var> ’s frame.

trans-unit.source: If <var>window</var> is not large enough to accommodate a scroll bar of the desired dimension, this leaves the corresponding scroll bar unchanged.
trans-unit.target: Si la <var>window</var> no es lo suficientemente grande para acomodar una barra de desplazamiento de la dimensión deseada, esto deja la barra de desplazamiento correspondiente sin cambios.

trans-unit.source: If <var>window</var> is not large enough to accommodate fringes of the desired width, this leaves the fringes of <var>window</var> unchanged.
trans-unit.target: Si la <var>window</var> no es lo suficientemente grande para acomodar franjas del ancho deseado, esto deja las franjas de la <var>window</var> sin cambios.

trans-unit.source: If <var>window</var> is not large enough to accommodate margins of the desired width, this leaves the margins of <var>window</var> unchanged.
trans-unit.target: Si la <var>window</var> no es lo suficientemente grande para dar cabida a los márgenes del ancho deseado, esto deja los márgenes de la <var>window</var> sin cambios.

trans-unit.source: If window is part of a horizontal combination and the value of the option fit-window-to-buffer-horizontally (see below) is non-nil, this function adjusts window’s width. The new width of window is calculated from the maximum length of its buffer’s lines that follow the current start position of window. The optional argument max-width specifies a maximum width and defaults to the width of window’s frame. The optional argument min-width specifies a minimum width and defaults to window-min-width. Both max-width and min-width are specified in columns and include fringes, margins and scrollbars, if any.
trans-unit.target: Si la window es parte de una combinación horizontal y el valor de la opción fit-window-to-buffer-horizontally (ver más abajo) no es nil , esta función ajusta el ancho de la window . El nuevo ancho de la window se calcula a partir de la longitud máxima de las líneas de su búfer que siguen la posición inicial actual de la window . El argumento opcional max-width especifica un ancho máximo y por defecto es el ancho del marco de la window . El argumento opcional min-width especifica un ancho mínimo y el valor predeterminado es window-min-width . Tanto max-width y min-width se especifican en columnas e incluyen franjas, márgenes y barras de desplazamiento, si las hay.

trans-unit.source: If window is part of a vertical combination, this function adjusts window’s height. The new height is calculated from the actual height of the accessible portion of its buffer. The optional argument max-height, if non-nil, specifies the maximum total height that this function can give window. The optional argument min-height, if non-nil, specifies the minimum total height that it can give, which overrides the variable window-min-height. Both max-height and min-height are specified in lines and include mode and header line and a bottom divider, if any.
trans-unit.target: Si la window es parte de una combinación vertical, esta función ajusta la altura de la window . La nueva altura se calcula a partir de la altura real de la parte accesible de su zona de influencia. El argumento opcional max-height , si no es nil , especifica la altura total máxima que esta función puede dar a la window . El argumento opcional min-height , si no es nil , especifica la altura total mínima que puede dar, que anula la variable window-min-height . Tanto max-height y min-height se especifican en las líneas y el modo y línea de cabecera y un divisor de parte inferior, en su caso incluyen.

trans-unit.source: If window is selected, this simply does goto-char in window’s buffer.
trans-unit.target: Si se selecciona la window , esto simplemente hace goto-char en el búfer de la window .

trans-unit.source: If window shall be deleted, is the only window on its frame and there are other frames on that frame’s terminal, the value of the optional argument bury-or-kill determines how to proceed with the window. If bury-or-kill equals kill, the frame is deleted unconditionally. Otherwise, the fate of the frame is determined by calling frame-auto-hide-function (see below) with that frame as sole argument.
trans-unit.target: Si la window se eliminará, es la única ventana en su marco y hay otros marcos en la terminal de ese marco, el valor del argumento opcional bury-or-kill determina cómo proceder con la ventana. Si bury-or-kill es igual a kill , el marco se elimina incondicionalmente. De lo contrario, el destino del marco se determina llamando a frame-auto-hide-function (ver más abajo) con ese marco como único argumento.

trans-unit.source: If <var>x</var> is finite, then <var>s</var> is a floating-point number between 0.5 (inclusive) and 1.0 (exclusive), <var>e</var> is an integer, and <var>x</var> = <var>s</var> * 2**<var>e</var>. If <var>x</var> is zero or infinity, then <var>s</var> is the same as <var>x</var>. If <var>x</var> is a NaN, then <var>s</var> is also a NaN. If <var>x</var> is zero, then <var>e</var> is 0.
trans-unit.target: Si <var>x</var> es finito, entonces <var>s</var> es un número de punto flotante entre 0.5 (inclusive) y 1.0 (exclusivo), <var>e</var> es un número entero y <var>x</var> = <var>s</var> * 2 ** <var>e</var> . Si <var>x</var> es cero o infinito, entonces <var>s</var> es lo mismo que <var>x</var> . Si <var>x</var> es un NaN, entonces <var>s</var> también es un NaN. Si <var>x</var> es cero, entonces <var>e</var> es 0.

trans-unit.source: If ACLs are not supported or the file does not exist, then the return value is nil.
trans-unit.target: Si las ACL no son compatibles o el archivo no existe, el valor de retorno es nil .

trans-unit.source: If Auto Compression mode is enabled, as it is by default, then if load can not find a file, it searches for a compressed version of the file before trying other file names. It decompresses and loads it if it exists. It looks for compressed versions by appending each of the suffixes in jka-compr-load-suffixes to the file name. The value of this variable must be a list of strings. Its standard value is (".gz").
trans-unit.target: Si el modo Auto Compresión está habilitado, como lo está de forma predeterminada, si load no puede encontrar un archivo, busca una versión comprimida del archivo antes de intentar con otros nombres de archivo. Lo descomprime y lo carga si existe. Busca versiones comprimidas agregando cada uno de los sufijos en jka-compr-load-suffixes al nombre del archivo. El valor de esta variable debe ser una lista de cadenas. Su valor estándar es (".gz") .

trans-unit.source: If Edebug detects a syntax error while instrumenting, it leaves point at the erroneous code and signals an invalid-read-syntax error. Example:
trans-unit.target: Si Edebug detecta un error de sintaxis durante la instrumentación, deja un punto en el código erróneo y señala un error de invalid-read-syntax . Ejemplo:

trans-unit.source: If Emacs exits due to signaling an error in batch mode, the exit status of the Emacs command is non-zero:
trans-unit.target: Si Emacs sale debido a la sealizacin de un error en el modo batch,el estado de salida del comando Emacs es distinto de cero:

trans-unit.source: If Emacs is built with GTK+ or Nextstep, the tool bar can only show one line, so this variable has no effect.
trans-unit.target: Si Emacs se construye con GTK+o Nextstep,la barra de herramientas slo puede mostrar una lnea,por lo que esta variable no tiene ningn efecto.

trans-unit.source: If Emacs is idle, this function returns the length of time Emacs has been idle, using the same format as current-time (see Time of Day).
trans-unit.target: Si Emacs está inactivo, esta función devuelve la cantidad de tiempo que Emacs ha estado inactivo, usando el mismo formato que current-time (ver Hora del día ).

trans-unit.source: If SELinux is not supported or the file does not exist, then the return value is (nil nil nil nil).
trans-unit.target: Si SELinux no es compatible o el archivo no existe, entonces el valor de retorno es (nil nil nil nil) .

trans-unit.source: If Transient Mark mode is enabled or force is non-nil, this function deactivates the mark and runs the normal hook deactivate-mark-hook. Otherwise, it does nothing.
trans-unit.target: Si el modo Transient Mark está habilitado o la force no es nil , esta función desactiva la marca y ejecuta el gancho normal deactivate-mark-hook . De lo contrario, no hace nada.

trans-unit.source: If Transient Mark mode is enabled, and mark-even-if-inactive is nil, mark signals an error if the mark is inactive. However, if force is non-nil, then mark disregards inactivity of the mark, and returns the mark position (or nil) anyway.
trans-unit.target: Si el modo Marca transitoria está habilitado y la mark-even-if-inactive está inactiva es nil , la mark indica un error si la marca está inactiva. Sin embargo, si la force no es nil , la mark ignora la inactividad de la marca y devuelve la posición de la marca (o nil ) de todos modos.

trans-unit.source: If Transient Mark mode is enabled, certain editing commands that normally apply to text near point, apply instead to the region when the mark is active. This is the main motivation for using Transient Mark mode. (Another is that this enables highlighting of the region when the mark is active. See Display.)
trans-unit.target: Si el modo Transient Mark está habilitado, ciertos comandos de edición que normalmente se aplican al texto cerca del punto, se aplican en su lugar a la región cuando la marca está activa. Esta es la principal motivación para utilizar el modo Transient Mark. (Otra es que esto permite resaltar la región cuando la marca está activa. Ver Pantalla ).

trans-unit.source: If a ‘
trans-unit.target: Si un '

trans-unit.source: If a defcustom does not specify any :group, the last group defined with defgroup in the same file will be used. This way, most defcustom do not need an explicit :group.
trans-unit.target: Si defcustom no especifica any :group , se utilizará el último grupo definido con defgroup en el mismo archivo. De esta manera, la mayoría de defcustom no necesitan un explícito :group .

trans-unit.source: If a throw is executed during the execution of body, specifying the same value tag, the catch form exits immediately; the value it returns is whatever was specified as the second argument of throw.
trans-unit.target: Si se ejecuta un throw durante la ejecución de body , especificando la misma tag valor , el formulario de catch cierra inmediatamente; el valor que devuelve es el que se especificó como segundo argumento de throw .

trans-unit.source: If a symbol is not buffer-local for the current buffer, and is not marked automatically buffer-local, setq-default has the same effect as setq. If symbol is buffer-local for the current buffer, then this changes the value that other buffers will see (as long as they don’t have a buffer-local value), but not the value that the current buffer sees.
trans-unit.target: Si un symbol no es local al búfer para el búfer actual y no se marca automáticamente como local al búfer, setq-default tiene el mismo efecto que setq . Si el symbol es local de búfer para el búfer actual, esto cambia el valor que verán otros búferes (siempre que no tengan un valor local de búfer), pero no el valor que ve el búfer actual.

trans-unit.source: If a tag has the form (eval expr), evaluate expr with the variable tag dynamically bound to the value of form. A non-nil result indicates a match.
trans-unit.target: Si una tag tiene la forma (eval expr) , evalúe expr con la tag variable vinculada dinámicamente al valor de form a . Un resultado que no sea nil indica una coincidencia.

trans-unit.source: If a backtrace frame starts with ‘
trans-unit.target: Si un marco de retroceso comienza con '

trans-unit.source: If a backup was made by renaming, the return value is a cons cell of the form (modesextra-alistbackupname), where modes are the mode bits of the original file, as returned by file-modes (see Testing Accessibility), extra-alist is an alist describing the original file’s extended attributes, as returned by file-extended-attributes (see Extended Attributes), and backupname is the name of the backup.
trans-unit.target: Si se hizo una copia de seguridad cambiando el nombre, el valor de retorno es una celda de contras del formulario ( modes extra-alist backupname ), donde los modes son los bits de modo del archivo original, como lo devuelven file-modes (consulte Prueba de accesibilidad ), extra-alist es una alista que describe los atributos extendidos del archivo original, como lo devuelve el file-extended-attributes (ver Atributos extendidos ), y backupname es el nombre de la copia de seguridad.

trans-unit.source: If a buffer is read-only, then you cannot change its contents, although you may change your view of the contents by scrolling and narrowing.
trans-unit.target: Si un búfer es de solo lectura , no puede cambiar su contenido, aunque puede cambiar su vista del contenido desplazándose y reduciendo.

trans-unit.source: If a character has a category property, we call it the property category of the character. It should be a symbol. The properties of the symbol serve as defaults for the properties of the character.
trans-unit.target: Si un personaje tiene una propiedad de category , la llamamos categoría de propiedad del personaje. Debería ser un símbolo. Las propiedades del símbolo sirven como valores predeterminados para las propiedades del personaje.

trans-unit.source: If a character has a category property, we call it the property category of the character. It should be a symbol. The properties of this symbol serve as defaults for the properties of the character.
trans-unit.target: Si un personaje tiene una propiedad de category , la llamamos categoría de propiedad del personaje. Debería ser un símbolo. Las propiedades de este símbolo sirven como valores predeterminados para las propiedades del personaje.

trans-unit.source: If a character has a non-nil entry in an active display table, the display table takes effect; in this case, Emacs does not consult glyphless-char-display at all.
trans-unit.target: Si un carácter tiene una entrada no nil en una tabla de visualización activa, la tabla de visualización tiene efecto; en este caso, Emacs no consulta la glyphless-char-display en absoluto.

trans-unit.source: If a character has the property modification-hooks, then its value should be a list of functions; modifying that character calls all of those functions before the actual modification. Each function receives two arguments: the beginning and end of the part of the buffer being modified. Note that if a particular modification hook function appears on several characters being modified by a single primitive, you can’t predict how many times the function will be called. Furthermore, insertion will not modify any existing character, so this hook will only be run when removing some characters, replacing them with others, or changing their text-properties.
trans-unit.target: Si un carácter tiene la propiedad modification-hooks , entonces su valor debería ser una lista de funciones; modificar ese carácter llama a todas esas funciones antes de la modificación real. Cada función recibe dos argumentos: el principio y el final de la parte del búfer que se está modificando. Tenga en cuenta que si una función de enlace de modificación en particular aparece en varios caracteres que están siendo modificados por una sola primitiva, no puede predecir cuántas veces se llamará a la función. Además, la inserción no modificará ningún carácter existente, por lo que este enlace solo se ejecutará al eliminar algunos caracteres, reemplazarlos por otros o cambiar sus propiedades de texto.

trans-unit.source: If a character has the property read-only, then modifying that character is not allowed. Any command that would do so gets an error, text-read-only. If the property value is a string, that string is used as the error message.
trans-unit.target: Si un personaje tiene la propiedad read-only , no se permite modificar ese carácter. Cualquier comando que lo haga obtiene un error, text-read-only . Si el valor de la propiedad es una cadena, esa cadena se utiliza como mensaje de error.

trans-unit.source: If a character’s front-sticky property is t, then all its properties are front-sticky. If the front-sticky property is a list, then the sticky properties of the character are those whose names are in the list. For example, if a character has a front-sticky property whose value is (face read-only), then insertion before the character can inherit its face property and its read-only property, but no others.
trans-unit.target: Si la propiedad front-sticky de un personaje es t , entonces todas sus propiedades son front-sticky. Si la propiedad front-sticky es una lista, entonces las propiedades sticky del carácter son aquellas cuyos nombres están en la lista. Por ejemplo, si un carácter tiene una propiedad front-sticky cuyo valor es (face read-only) , entonces la inserción antes de que el personaje pueda heredar su propiedad de face y su propiedad de read-only , pero no otras.

trans-unit.source: If a command <var>other-command</var> is remapped to <var>command</var>:
trans-unit.target: Si un comando <var>other-command</var> se reasigna a <var>command</var> :

trans-unit.source: If a command ends with point inside or at the boundary of invisible text, the main editing loop relocates point to one of the two ends of the invisible text. Emacs chooses the direction of relocation so that it is the same as the overall movement direction of the command; if in doubt, it prefers a position where an inserted char would not inherit the invisible property. Additionally, if the text is not replaced by an ellipsis and the command only moved within the invisible text, then point is moved one extra character so as to try and reflect the command’s movement by a visible movement of the cursor.
trans-unit.target: Si un comando termina con un punto dentro o en el límite del texto invisible, el ciclo de edición principal reubica el punto en uno de los dos extremos del texto invisible.
